Title: any_value(arg)
Description: Returns the first non-null value from arg. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: first(A)
Description: arbitrary(arg)
Returns the first value (null or non-null) from arg. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: bit_and(arg)
Description: Returns the bitwise AND of all bits in a given expression.

Title: octet_length(bitstring)
Description: Returns the number of bytes in the bitstring.

Title: set_bit(bitstring, index, new_value)
Description: Sets the nth bit in bitstring to newvalue; the first (leftmost) bit is indexed 0. Returns a new bitstring.

Title: bit_and(arg)
Description: Returns the bitwise AND operation performed on all bitstrings in a given expression.

Title: bit_or(arg)
Description: Returns the bitwise OR operation performed on all bitstrings in a given expression.

Title: bit_xor(arg)
Description: Returns the bitwise XOR operation performed on all bitstrings in a given expression.

Title: bitstring_agg(arg)
Description: Returns a bitstring with bits set for each distinct position defined in arg.

The bitstring_agg function takes any integer type as input and returns a bitstring with bits set for each distinct value. The left-most bit represents the smallest value in the column and the right-most bit the maximum value. If possible, the min and max are retrieved from the column statistics. Otherwise, it is also possible to provide the min and max values.

Title: bitstring_agg(arg, min, max)
Description: Returns a bitstring with bits set for each distinct position defined in arg. All positions must be within the range [min, max] or an Out of Range Error will be thrown.

Title: blob || blob
Description: BLOB concatenation.

Title: decode(blob)
Description: Converts blob to VARCHAR. Fails if blob is not valid UTF-8.
Convert blob to VARCHAR. Fails if blob is not valid UTF-8.

Title: encode(string)
Description: Converts the string to BLOB. Converts UTF-8 characters into literal encoding.

Title: bit_or(arg)
Description: Returns the bitwise OR of all bits in a given expression.

Title: hex(blob)
Description: Converts blob to VARCHAR using hexadecimal encoding.

Title: octet_length(blob)
Description: Number of bytes in blob.

Title: read_blob(source)
Description: Returns the content from source (a filename, a list of filenames, or a glob pattern) as a BLOB. See the read_blob guide for more details.

Title: current_date
Description: Current date (at start of current transaction).

Title: date_add(date, interval)
Description: Add the interval to the date.

Title: date_diff(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: The number of partition boundaries between the dates.

Title: date_part(part, date)
Description: Get the subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: date_sub(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: The number of complete partitions between the dates.

Title: date_trunc(part, date)
Description: Truncate to specified precision.

Title: date_diff
Description: datediff(part, startdate, enddate)
The number of partition boundaries between the dates. Alias of date_diff.
The number of partition boundaries between the dates.

Title: bit_xor(arg)
Description: Returns the bitwise XOR of all bits in a given expression.

Title: date_part
Description: datepart(part, date)
Get the subfield (equivalent to extract). Alias of date_part.
Get the subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: date_sub
Description: datesub(part, startdate, enddate)
The number of complete partitions between the dates. Alias of date_sub.
The number of complete partitions between the dates.

Title: date_trunc
Description: datetrunc(part, date)
Truncate to specified precision. Alias of date_trunc.
Truncate to specified precision.

Title: dayname(date)
Description: The (English) name of the weekday.

Title: extract(part from date)
Description: Get subfield from a date.

Title: greatest(date, date)
Description: The later of two dates.

Title: isfinite(date)
Description: Returns true if the date is finite, false otherwise.

Title: isinf(date)
Description: Returns true if the date is infinite, false otherwise.

Title: last_day(date)
Description: The last day of the corresponding month in the date.

Title: least(date, date)
Description: The earlier of two dates.

Title: bitstring_agg(arg)
Description: Returns a bitstring whose length corresponds to the range of the non-null (integer) values, with bits set at the location of each (distinct) value.

Title: make_date(year, month, day)
Description: The date for the given parts.

Title: monthname(date)
Description: The (English) name of the month.

Title: strftime(date, format)
Description: Converts a date to a string according to the format string.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, date[, offset])
Description: Truncate date by the specified interval bucket_width. Buckets are offset by offset interval.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, date[, origin])
Description: Truncate date by the specified interval bucket_width. Buckets are aligned relative to origin date. origin defaults to 2000-01-03 for buckets that don't include a month or year interval, and to 2000-01-01 for month and year buckets.

Title: today()
Description: Current date (start of current transaction).

Title: bool_and(arg)
Description: Returns true if every input value is true, otherwise false.

Title: century(date)
Description: Century.

Title: day(date)
Description: Day.

Title: dayofmonth(date)
Description: Day (synonym).

Title: dayofweek(date)
Description: Numeric weekday (Sunday = 0, Saturday = 6).

Title: dayofyear(date)
Description: Day of the year (starts from 1, i.e., January 1 = 1).

Title: decade(date)
Description: Decade (year / 10).

Title: epoch(date)
Description: Seconds since 1970-01-01.

Title: era(date)
Description: Calendar era.

Title: hour(date)
Description: Hours.

Title: isodow(date)
Description: Numeric ISO weekday (Monday = 1, Sunday = 7).

Title: bool_or(arg)
Description: Returns true if any input value is true, otherwise false.

Title: isoyear(date)
Description: ISO Year number (Starts on Monday of week containing Jan 4th).

Title: microsecond(date)
Description: Sub-minute microseconds.

Title: millennium(date)
Description: Millennium.

Title: millisecond(date)
Description: Sub-minute milliseconds.

Title: minute(date)
Description: Minutes.

Title: month(date)
Description: Month.

Title: quarter(date)
Description: Quarter.

Title: second(date)
Description: Seconds.

Title: timezone_hour(date)
Description: Time zone offset hour portion.

Title: timezone_minute(date)
Description: Time zone offset minutes portion.

Title: count(*)
Description: count()
Returns the number of rows in a group.

Title: timezone(date)
Description: Time Zone offset in minutes.

Title: week(date)
Description: ISO Week.

Title: weekday(date)
Description: Numeric weekday synonym (Sunday = 0, Saturday = 6).

Title: weekofyear(date)
Description: ISO Week (synonym).

Title: year(date)
Description: Year.

Title: yearweek(date)
Description: BIGINT of combined ISO Year number and 2-digit version of ISO Week number.

Title: enum_code(enum_value)
Description: Returns the numeric value backing the given enum value.

Title: enum_first(enum)
Description: Returns the first value of the input enum type.

Title: enum_last(enum)
Description: Returns the last value of the input enum type.

Title: enum_range(enum)
Description: Returns all values of the input enum type as an array.

Title: count(arg)
Description: Returns the number of non-null values in arg.

Title: enum_range_boundary(enum, enum)
Description: Returns the range between the two given enum values as an array.

Returns the range between the two given enum values as an array. The values must be of the same enum type. When the first parameter is NULL, the result starts with the first value of the enum type. When the second parameter is NULL, the result ends with the last value of the enum type.

Title: date_part(part, interval)
Description: Extract datepart component (equivalent to extract). See INTERVAL for the sometimes surprising rules governing this extraction.

Title: datepart(part, interval)
Description: Alias of date_part.

Title: extract(part FROM interval)
Description: Alias of date_part.

Title: epoch(interval)
Description: Get total number of seconds, as double precision floating point number, in interval.

Title: to_centuries(integer)
Description: Construct a century interval.

Title: to_days(integer)
Description: Construct a day interval.

Title: to_decades(integer)
Description: Construct a decade interval.

Title: to_hours(integer)
Description: Construct a hour interval.

Title: to_microseconds(integer)
Description: Construct a microsecond interval.

Title: favg(arg)
Description: Calculates the average using a more accurate floating point summation (Kahan Sum).

Title: to_millennia(integer)
Description: Construct a millennium interval.

Title: to_milliseconds(integer)
Description: Construct a millisecond interval.

Title: to_minutes(integer)
Description: Construct a minute interval.

Title: to_months(integer)
Description: Construct a month interval.

Title: to_seconds(integer)
Description: Construct a second interval.

Title: to_weeks(integer)
Description: Construct a week interval.

Title: to_years(integer)
Description: Construct a year interval.

Title: array_apply
Description: list_apply
apply
array_transform
list_transform(list, lambda)
Returns a list that is the result of applying the lambda function to each element of the input list.
Returns a list that is the result of applying the lambda function to each element of the input list. For more information, see Transform.

Title: filter
Description: array_filter
list_filter(list, lambda)
Constructs a list from those elements of the input list for which the lambda function returns true.
Constructs a list from those elements of the input list for which the lambda function returns true. For more information, see Filter.

Title: reduce
Description: array_reduce
list_reduce(list, lambda)

Reduces all elements of the input list into a single value by executing the lambda function on a running result and the next list element. The list must have at least one element – the use of an initial accumulator value is currently not supported.

Reduces all elements of the input list into a single value by executing the lambda function on a running result and the next list element. The list must have at least one element – the use of an initial accumulator value is currently not supported. For more information, see Reduce.

Title: arbitrary(A)
Description: first(arg)
Returns the first value (null or non-null) from arg. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: list_extract
Description: list[index]
Bracket notation serves as an alias for list_extract.

Title: list_slice
Description: list[begin:end]
Bracket notation with colon is an alias for list_slice.

Title: argMax(arg, val)
Description: arg_max(arg, val)
Finds the row with the maximum val and calculates the arg expression at that row. Rows where the value of the arg or val expression is NULL are ignored. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: kahan_sum
Description: sumKahan
fsum(arg)
Calculates the sum using a more accurate floating point summation (Kahan Sum).

Title: list[begin:end:step]
Description: list_slice in bracket notation with an added step feature.

Title: array_pop_back(list)
Description: Returns the list without the last element.

Title: array_pop_front(list)
Description: Returns the list without the first element.

Title: flatten(list_of_lists)
Description: Concatenate a list of lists into a single list. This only flattens one level of the list (see examples).

Title: array_length
Description: len(list)
Return the length of the list.

Title: array_aggr
Description: array_aggregate
aggregate
list_aggr
list_aggregate(list, name)
Executes the aggregate function name on the elements of list. See the List Aggregates section for more details.

Title: list_any_value(list)
Description: Returns the first non-null value in the list.

Title: array_push_back
Description: array_append
list_append(list, element)
Appends element to list.

Title: array_cat
Description: array_concat
list_cat
list_concat(list1, list2)
Concatenate two lists. NULL inputs are skipped. See also ||

Title: array_has
Description: array_contains
list_has
list_contains(list, element)
Returns true if the list contains the element.

Title: geometric_mean(A)
Description: geomean(arg)
Calculates the geometric mean of all non-null values in arg.

Title: list_cosine_similarity(list1, list2)
Description: Compute the cosine similarity between two lists.

Title: list_cosine_distance(list1, list2)
Description: Compute the cosine distance between two lists. Equivalent to 1.0 - list_cosine_similarity.
Compute the cosine distance between two lists. Equivalent to 1.0 - list_cosine_similarity

Title: list_distance(list1, list2)
Description: Calculates the Euclidean distance between two points with coordinates given in two inputs lists of equal length.

Title: array_distinct
Description: list_distinct(list)
Removes all duplicates and NULL values from a list. Does not preserve the original order.

Title: list_inner_product
Description: list_dot_product(list1, list2)
Computes the dot product of two same-sized lists of numbers.

Title: list_negative_inner_product
Description: list_negative_dot_product(list1, list2)
Computes the negative dot product of two same-sized lists of numbers. Equivalent to - list_dot_product.
Computes the negative dot product of two same-sized lists of numbers. Equivalent to - list_dot_product

Title: array_extract
Description: list_element
list_extract(list, index)
Extract the indexth (1-based) value from the list.

Title: filter
Description: array_filter
list_filter(list, lambda)
Constructs a list from those elements of the input list for which the lambda function returns true. See the Lambda Functions page for more details.

Title: array_grade_up
Description: list_grade_up(list)
Works like sort, but the results are the indexes that correspond to the position in the original list instead of the actual values.

Title: array_has_all
Description: list_has_all(list, sub-list)
Returns true if all elements of sub-list exist in list.

Title: histogram(arg)
Description: Returns a MAP of key-value pairs representing buckets and counts.

Title: array_has_any
Description: list_has_any(list1, list2)
Returns true if any elements exist is both lists.

Title: array_intersect
Description: list_intersect(list1, list2)
Returns a list of all the elements that exist in both l1 and l2, without duplicates.

Title: array_indexof
Description: array_position
list_indexof
list_position(list, element)
Returns the index of the element if the list contains the element. If the element is not found, it returns NULL.

Title: array_push_front
Description: array_prepend
list_prepend(element, list)
Prepends element to list.

Title: reduce
Description: array_reduce
list_reduce(list, lambda)
Returns a single value that is the result of applying the lambda function to each element of the input list. See the Lambda Functions page for more details.

Title: array_resize
Description: list_resize(list, size[, value])
Resizes the list to contain size elements. Initializes new elements with value or NULL if value is not set.

Title: array_reverse_sort
Description: list_reverse_sort(list)
Sorts the elements of the list in reverse order. See the Sorting Lists section for more details about the NULL sorting order.

Title: array_reverse
Description: list_reverse(list)
Reverses the list.

Title: array_select
Description: list_select(value_list, index_list)
Returns a list based on the elements selected by the index_list.

Title: array_slice
Description: list_slice(list, begin, end, step)
list_slice with added step feature.

Title: last(arg)
Description: Returns the last value of a column. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: list_slice(list, begin, end)
Description: Extract a sublist using slice conventions. Negative values are accepted. See slicing.

Title: array_sort
Description: list_sort(list)
Sorts the elements of the list. See the Sorting Lists section for more details about the sorting order and the NULL sorting order.

Title: array_apply
Description: list_apply
apply
array_transform
list_transform(list, lambda)
Returns a list that is the result of applying the lambda function to each element of the input list. See the Lambda Functions page for more details.

Title: array_unique
Description: list_unique(list)
Counts the unique elements of a list.

Title: list_pack
Description: list_value(any, ...)
Create a LIST containing the argument values.

Title: array_where
Description: list_where(value_list, mask_list)
Returns a list with the BOOLEANs in mask_list applied as a mask to the value_list.

Title: list_zip(list_1, list_2, ...[, truncate])
Description: Zips k LISTs to a new LIST whose length will be that of the longest list. Its elements are structs of k elements from each list list_1, …, list_k, missing elements are replaced with NULL. If truncate is set, all lists are truncated to the smallest list length.

Title: unnest(list)
Description: Unnests a list by one level. Note that this is a special function that alters the cardinality of the result. See the unnest page for more details.

Title: array_agg
Description: list(arg)
Returns a LIST containing all the values of a column. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: max(arg)
Description: Returns the maximum value present in arg.

Title: max(arg, n)
Description: Returns a LIST containing the arg values for the "top" n rows ordered by arg descending.

Title: max_by(arg, val)
Description: Finds the row with the maximum val. Calculates the arg expression at that row. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: max_by(arg, val, n)
Description: Returns a LIST containing the arg expressions for the "top" n rows ordered by val descending.

Title: array_zip
Description: list_zip(list1, list2, ...)

Zips k LISTs to a new LIST whose length will be that of the longest list. Its elements are structs of k elements from each list list_1, …, list_k, missing elements are replaced with NULL. If truncate is set, all lists are truncated to the smallest list length.

Title: cardinality(map)
Description: Return the size of the map (or the number of entries in the map).

Title: element_at(map, key)
Description: Return a list containing the value for a given key or an empty list if the key is not contained in the map. The type of the key provided in the second parameter must match the type of the map's keys else an error is returned.

Title: map_contains(map, key)
Description: Checks if a map contains a given key.

Title: map_contains_entry(map, key, value)
Description: Check if a map contains a given key-value pair.

Title: min(arg)
Description: Returns the minimum value present in arg.

Title: map_contains_value(map, value)
Description: Checks if a map contains a given value.

Title: map_entries(map)
Description: Return a list of struct(k, v) for each key-value pair in the map.

Title: map_extract(map, key)
Description: Alias of element_at. Return a list containing the value for a given key or an empty list if the key is not contained in the map. The type of the key provided in the second parameter must match the type of the map's keys else an error is returned.

Title: map_from_entries(STRUCT(k, v)[])
Description: Returns a map created from the entries of the array.

Title: map_keys(map)
Description: Return a list of all keys in the map.

Title: map_values(map)
Description: Return a list of all values in the map.

Title: map()
Description: Returns an empty map.

Title: map[entry]
Description: Alias for element_at.

Title: abs
Description: Absolute value. Parentheses are optional if x is a column name.
abs(x)
Absolute value.

Title: argMax(arg, val, n)
Description: arg_max(arg, val, n)
The generalized case of arg_max for n values: returns a LIST containing the arg expressions for the top n rows ordered by val descending. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: min(arg, n)
Description: Returns a LIST containing the arg values for the "bottom" n rows ordered by arg ascending.

Title: acos(x)
Description: Computes the arccosine of x.

Title: add(x, y)
Description: Alias for x + y.

Title: asin(x)
Description: Computes the arcsine of x.

Title: atan(x)
Description: Computes the arctangent of x.

Title: atan2(y, x)
Description: Computes the arctangent (y, x).

Title: bit_count(x)
Description: Returns the number of bits that are set.

Title: cbrt(x)
Description: Returns the cube root of the number.

Title: ceil(x)
Description: Rounds the number up.

Title: ceiling(x)
Description: Rounds the number up. Alias of ceil.

Title: cos(x)
Description: Computes the cosine of x.

Title: argMin(arg, val)
Description: min_by(arg, val)
Finds the row with the minimum val. Calculates the arg expression at that row. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: cot(x)
Description: Computes the cotangent of x.

Title: degrees(x)
Description: Converts radians to degrees.

Title: divide(x, y)
Description: Alias for x // y.

Title: even(x)
Description: Round to next even number by rounding away from zero.

Title: exp(x)
Description: Computes e ** x.

Title: factorial(x)
Description: See ! operator. Computes the product of the current integer and all integers below it.

Title: fdiv(x, y)
Description: Performs integer division (x // y) but returns a DOUBLE value.

Title: floor(x)
Description: Rounds the number down.

Title: fmod(x, y)
Description: Calculates the modulo value. Always returns a DOUBLE value.

Title: gamma(x)
Description: Interpolation of the factorial of x - 1. Fractional inputs are allowed.

Title: argMin(arg, val, n)
Description: min_by(arg, val, n)
Returns a LIST containing the arg expressions for the "bottom" n rows ordered by val ascending.

Title: gcd(x, y)
Description: Computes the greatest common divisor of x and y.

Title: greatest_common_divisor(x, y)
Description: Computes the greatest common divisor of x and y.

Title: greatest(x1, x2, ...)
Description: Selects the largest value.

Title: isfinite(x)
Description: Returns true if the floating point value is finite, false otherwise.

Title: isinf(x)
Description: Returns true if the floating point value is infinite, false otherwise.

Title: isnan(x)
Description: Returns true if the floating point value is not a number, false otherwise.

Title: lcm(x, y)
Description: Computes the least common multiple of x and y.

Title: least_common_multiple(x, y)
Description: Computes the least common multiple of x and y.

Title: least(x1, x2, ...)
Description: Selects the smallest value.

Title: lgamma(x)
Description: Computes the log of the gamma function.

Title: product(arg)
Description: Calculates the product of all non-null values in arg.

Title: ln(x)
Description: Computes the natural logarithm of x.

Title: log(x)
Description: Computes the base-10 logarithm of x.
Computes the base-10 log of x.

Title: log10(x)
Description: Alias of log. Computes the base-10 logarithm of x.
Alias of log. Computes the base-10 log of x.

Title: log2(x)
Description: Computes the base-2 log of x.

Title: multiply(x, y)
Description: Alias for x * y.

Title: nextafter(x, y)
Description: Return the next floating point value after x in the direction of y.

Title: pi()
Description: Returns the value of pi.

Title: pow(x, y)
Description: Computes x to the power of y.

Title: power(x, y)
Description: Alias of pow. computes x to the power of y.

Title: radians(x)
Description: Converts degrees to radians.

Title: listagg(arg, sep)
Description: group_concat(arg, sep)
string_agg(arg, sep)
Concatenates the column string values with a separator. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: random()
Description: Returns a random number x in the range 0.0 <= x < 1.0.

Title: round_even(v NUMERIC, s INTEGER)
Description: Alias of roundbankers(v, s). Round to s decimal places using the rounding half to even rule. Values s < 0 are allowed.

Title: round(v NUMERIC, s INTEGER)
Description: Round to s decimal places. Values s < 0 are allowed.

Title: setseed(x)
Description: Sets the seed to be used for the random function.

Title: sign(x)
Description: Returns the sign of x as -1, 0 or 1.

Title: signbit(x)
Description: Returns whether the signbit is set or not.

Title: sin(x)
Description: Computes the sin of x.

Title: sqrt(x)
Description: Returns the square root of the number.

Title: subtract(x, y)
Description: Alias for x - y.

Title: tan(x)
Description: Computes the tangent of x.

Title: sum(arg)
Description: Calculates the sum of all non-null values in arg.

Title: trunc(x)
Description: Truncates the number.

Title: xor(x, y)
Description: Bitwise XOR.

Title: regexp_extract(string, pattern[, group = 0][, options])
Description: If string contains the regexp pattern, returns the capturing group specified by optional parameter group. The group must be a constant value. If no group is given, it defaults to 0. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: regexp_extract(string, pattern, name_list[, options])
Description: If string contains the regexp pattern, returns the capturing groups as a struct with corresponding names from name_list.
If string contains the regexp pattern, returns the capturing groups as a struct with corresponding names from name_list. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: regexp_extract_all(string, regex[, group = 0][, options])
Description: Split the string along the regex and extract all occurrences of group.
Split the string along the regex and extract all occurrences of group. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: regexp_full_match(string, regex[, options])
Description: Returns true if the entire string matches the regex.
Returns true if the entire string matches the regex. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: regexp_matches(string, pattern[, options])
Description: Returns true if  string contains the regexp pattern, false otherwise.
Returns true if  string contains the regexp pattern, false otherwise. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: regexp_replace(string, pattern, replacement[, options])
Description: If string contains the regexp pattern, replaces the matching part with replacement.
If string contains the regexp pattern, replaces the matching part with replacement. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: approx_count_distinct(x)
Description: Gives the approximate count of distinct elements using HyperLogLog.

Title: regexp_split_to_array(string, regex[, options])
Description: Alias of string_split_regex. Splits the string along the regex.
Alias of string_split_regex. Splits the string along the regex. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: regexp_split_to_table(string, regex[, options])
Description: Splits the string along the regex and returns a row for each part.
Splits the string along the regex and returns a row for each part. A set of optional options can be set.

Title: struct.entry
Description: Dot notation that serves as an alias for struct_extract from named STRUCTs.

Title: struct[entry]
Description: Bracket notation that serves as an alias for struct_extract from named STRUCTs.

Title: struct[idx]
Description: Bracket notation that serves as an alias for struct_extract from unnamed STRUCTs (tuples), using an index (1-based).

Title: row(any, ...)
Description: Create an unnamed STRUCT (tuple) containing the argument values.

Title: struct_extract(struct, 'entry')
Description: Extract the named entry from the STRUCT.

Title: struct_extract(struct, idx)
Description: Extract the entry from an unnamed STRUCT (tuple) using an index (1-based).

Title: struct_insert(struct, name := any, ...)
Description: Add field(s)/value(s) to an existing STRUCT with the argument values. The entry name(s) will be the bound variable name(s).

Title: struct_pack(name := any, ...)
Description: Create a STRUCT containing the argument values. The entry name will be the bound variable name.

Title: approx_quantile(x, pos)
Description: Gives the approximate quantile using T-Digest.

Title: starts_with
Description: string ^@ search_string
Return true if string begins with search_string.
Concatenate two strings. Any NULL input results in NULL. See also concat(string, ...).

Title: array_extract
Description: string[index]
Extract a single character using a (1-based) index.

Title: array_slice
Description: string[begin:end]
Extract a string using slice conventions, see slicing.
Extract a string using slice conventions similar to Python. Missing begin or end arguments are interpreted as the beginning or end of the list respectively. Negative values are accepted.

Title: LIKE
Description: Returns true if the string matches the like specifier (see Pattern Matching).

Title: SIMILAR TO
Description: Returns true if the string matches the regex; identical to regexp_full_match (see Pattern Matching).
Returns true if the string matches the regex; identical to regexp_full_match (see Pattern Matching)

Title: list_extract
Description: list_element
array_extract(list, index)
Extract a single character using a (1-based) index.

Title: array_slice(list, begin, end)
Description: Extract a string using slice conventions. Negative values are accepted.
Extract a string using slice conventions (like in Python). Negative values are accepted.
array_slice('DuckDB', 3, 4)
array_slice('DuckDB', 3, NULL)
array_slice('DuckDB', 0, -3)

Title: ascii(string)
Description: Returns an integer that represents the Unicode code point of the first character of the string.

Title: bar(x, min, max[, width])
Description: Draw a band whose width is proportional to (x - min) and equal to width characters when x = max. width defaults to 80.

Title: reservoir_quantile(x, quantile, sample_size = 8192)
Description: Gives the approximate quantile using reservoir sampling, the sample size is optional and uses 8192 as a default size.

Title: bit_length(string)
Description: Number of bits in a string.

Title: chr(x)
Description: Returns a character which is corresponding the ASCII code value or Unicode code point.

Title: concat_ws(separator, string, ...)
Description: Concatenate many strings, separated by separator. NULL inputs are skipped.

Title: concat(string, ...)
Description: Concatenate many strings. NULL inputs are skipped. See also string || string.

Title: contains(string, search_string)
Description: Return true if search_string is found within string.

Title: suffix
Description: ends_with(string, search_string)
Return true if string ends with search_string.

Title: format_bytes(bytes)
Description: Converts bytes to a human-readable representation using units based on powers of 2 (KiB, MiB, GiB, etc.).

Title: format(format, parameters, ...)
Description: Formats a string using the fmt syntax.

Title: from_base64(string)
Description: Convert a base64 encoded string to a character string.

Title: greatest(x1, x2, ...)
Description: Selects the largest value using lexicographical ordering. Note that lowercase characters are considered “larger” than uppercase characters and collations are not supported.

Title: corr(y, x)
Description: The correlation coefficient.
covar_pop(y, x) / (stddev_pop(x) * stddev_pop(y))

Title: hash(value)
Description: Returns a UBIGINT with the hash of the value.

Title: ilike_escape(string, like_specifier, escape_character)
Description: Returns true if the string matches the like_specifier (see Pattern Matching) using case-insensitive matching. escape_character is used to search for wildcard characters in the string.

Title: instr(string, search_string)
Description: Return location of first occurrence of search_string in string, counting from 1. Returns 0 if no match found.

Title: least(x1, x2, ...)
Description: Selects the smallest value using lexicographical ordering. Note that uppercase characters are considered “smaller” than lowercase characters, and collations are not supported.

Title: left_grapheme(string, count)
Description: Extract the left-most grapheme clusters.

Title: left(string, count)
Description: Extract the left-most count characters.

Title: length_grapheme(string)
Description: Number of grapheme clusters in string.

Title: length(string)
Description: Number of characters in string.

Title: like_escape(string, like_specifier, escape_character)
Description: Returns true if the string matches the like_specifier (see Pattern Matching) using case-sensitive matching. escape_character is used to search for wildcard characters in the string.

Title: lcase
Description: lower(string)
Convert string to lower case.

Title: arg_max_null(arg, val)
Description: Finds the row with the maximum val and calculates the arg expression at that row. Rows where the val expression evaluates to NULL are ignored. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: covar_pop(y, x)
Description: The population covariance, which does not include bias correction.
(sum(x*y) - sum(x) * sum(y) / regr_count(y, x)) / regr_count(y, x), covar_samp(y, x) * (1 - 1 / regr_count(y, x))

Title: lpad(string, count, character)
Description: Pads the string  with the character from the left until it has count characters.

Title: ltrim(string, characters)
Description: Removes any occurrences of any of the characters from the left side of the string.

Title: ltrim(string)
Description: Removes any spaces from the left side of the string.
Removes any spaces from the left side of the string. In the example, the ␣ symbol denotes a space character.

Title: md5(string)
Description: Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a VARCHAR.

Title: md5_number(string)
Description: Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a HUGEINT.

Title: md5_number_lower(string)
Description: Returns the lower 64-bit segment of the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.
Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.

Title: md5_number_higher(string)
Description: Returns the higher 64-bit segment of the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.
Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.

Title: nfc_normalize(string)
Description: Convert string to Unicode NFC normalized string. Useful for comparisons and ordering if text data is mixed between NFC normalized and not.

Title: not_ilike_escape(string, like_specifier, escape_character)
Description: Returns false if the string matches the like_specifier (see Pattern Matching) using case-sensitive matching. escape_character is used to search for wildcard characters in the string.

Title: not_like_escape(string, like_specifier, escape_character)
Description: Returns false if the string matches the like_specifier (see Pattern Matching) using case-insensitive matching. escape_character is used to search for wildcard characters in the string.

Title: covar_samp(y, x)
Description: The sample covariance, which includes Bessel's bias correction.
(sum(x*y) - sum(x) * sum(y) / regr_count(y, x)) / (regr_count(y, x) - 1), covar_pop(y, x) / (1 - 1 / regr_count(y, x))

Title: ord(string)
Description: Return ASCII character code of the leftmost character in a string.

Title: parse_dirname(path, separator)
Description: Returns the top-level directory name from the given path. separator options: system, both_slash (default), forward_slash, backslash.

Title: parse_dirpath(path, separator)
Description: Returns the head of the path (the pathname until the last slash) similarly to Python's os.path.dirname function. separator options: system, both_slash (default), forward_slash, backslash.

Title: parse_filename(path, trim_extension, separator)
Description: Returns the last component of the path similarly to Python's os.path.basename function. If trim_extension is true, the file extension will be removed (defaults to false). separator options: system, both_slash (default), forward_slash, backslash.

Title: parse_path(path, separator)
Description: Returns a list of the components (directories and filename) in the path similarly to Python's pathlib.parts function. separator options: system, both_slash (default), forward_slash, backslash.

Title: position(search_string IN string)
Description: Return location of first occurrence of search_string in string, counting from 1. Returns 0 if no match found.

Title: printf(format, parameters...)
Description: Formats a string using printf syntax.

Title: read_text(source)
Description: Returns the content from source (a filename, a list of filenames, or a glob pattern) as a VARCHAR. The file content is first validated to be valid UTF-8. If read_text attempts to read a file with invalid UTF-8 an error is thrown suggesting to use read_blob instead. See the read_text guide for more details.

Title: regexp_escape(string)
Description: Escapes special patterns to turn string into a regular expression similarly to Python's re.escape function.

Title: regexp_extract(string, pattern[, group = 0])
Description: If string contains the regexp pattern, returns the capturing group specified by optional parameter group (see Pattern Matching).

Title: entropy(x)
Description: The log-2 entropy.

Title: regexp_extract(string, pattern, name_list)
Description: If string contains the regexp pattern, returns the capturing groups as a struct with corresponding names from name_list (see Pattern Matching).

Title: regexp_extract_all(string, regex[, group = 0])
Description: Split the string along the regex and extract all occurrences of group.

Title: regexp_full_match(string, regex)
Description: Returns true if the entire string matches the regex (see Pattern Matching).

Title: regexp_matches(string, pattern)
Description: Returns true if  string contains the regexp pattern, false otherwise (see Pattern Matching).

Title: regexp_replace(string, pattern, replacement)
Description: If string contains the regexp pattern, replaces the matching part with replacement (see Pattern Matching).

Title: str_split_regex
Description: string_split_regex
regexp_split_to_array(string, regex)
Splits the string along the regex.

Title: regexp_split_to_table(string, regex)
Description: Splits the string along the regex and returns a row for each part.

Title: repeat(string, count)
Description: Repeats the string count number of times.

Title: replace(string, source, target)
Description: Replaces any occurrences of the source with target in string.

Title: reverse(string)
Description: Reverses the string.

Title: kurtosis_pop(x)
Description: The excess kurtosis (Fisher’s definition) without bias correction.

Title: right_grapheme(string, count)
Description: Extract the right-most count grapheme clusters.

Title: right(string, count)
Description: Extract the right-most count characters.

Title: rpad(string, count, character)
Description: Pads the string with the character from the right until it has count characters.

Title: rtrim(string, characters)
Description: Removes any occurrences of any of the characters from the right side of the string.

Title: rtrim(string)
Description: Removes any spaces from the right side of the string.
Removes any spaces from the right side of the string. In the example, the ␣ symbol denotes a space character.

Title: sha256(value)
Description: Returns a VARCHAR with the SHA-256 hash of the value.

Title: split_part(string, separator, index)
Description: Split the string along the separator and return the data at the (1-based) index of the list. If the index is outside the bounds of the list, return an empty string (to match PostgreSQL's behavior).

Title: starts_with(string, search_string)
Description: Return true if string begins with search_string.

Title: regexp_split_to_array
Description: str_split_regex(string, regex)
Splits the string along the regex.

Title: string_split_regex(string, regex)
Description: Splits the string along the regex.

Title: kurtosis(x)
Description: The excess kurtosis (Fisher's definition) with bias correction according to the sample size.

Title: string_to_array
Description: str_split
string_split(string, separator)
Splits the string along the separator.

Title: strip_accents(string)
Description: Strips accents from string.

Title: strlen(string)
Description: Number of bytes in string.

Title: instr
Description: strpos(string, search_string)
Return location of first occurrence of search_string in string, counting from 1. Returns 0 if no match found.

Title: substr
Description: substring(string, start, length)
Extract substring of length characters starting from character start. Note that a start value of 1 refers to the first character of the string.

Title: substring_grapheme(string, start, length)
Description: Extract substring of length grapheme clusters starting from character start. Note that a start value of 1 refers to the first character of the string.

Title: base64
Description: to_base64(blob)
Convert a blob to a base64 encoded string.

Title: trim(string, characters)
Description: Removes any occurrences of any of the characters from either side of the string.

Title: trim(string)
Description: Removes any spaces from either side of the string.

Title: unicode(string)
Description: Returns the Unicode code of the first character of the string.
Returns the Unicode code of the first character of the string. Returns -1 when string is empty, and NULL when string is NULL.

Title: mad(x)
Description: The median absolute deviation. Temporal types return a positive INTERVAL.
median(abs(x - median(x)))

Title: ucase
Description: upper(string)
Convert string to upper case.

Title: damerau_levenshtein(s1, s2)
Description: Extension of Levenshtein distance to also include transposition of adjacent characters as an allowed edit operation. In other words, the minimum number of edit operations (insertions, deletions, substitutions or transpositions) required to change one string to another. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different.

Title: editdist3(s1, s2)
Description: Alias of levenshtein for SQLite compatibility. The minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions or substitutions) required to change one string to the other. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different.

Title: hamming(s1, s2)
Description: The Hamming distance between to strings, i.e., the number of positions with different characters for two strings of equal length. Strings must be of equal length. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different.

Title: jaccard(s1, s2)
Description: The Jaccard similarity between two strings. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different. Returns a number between 0 and 1.

Title: jaro_similarity(s1, s2)
Description: The Jaro similarity between two strings. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different. Returns a number between 0 and 1.

Title: jaro_winkler_similarity(s1, s2)
Description: The Jaro-Winkler similarity between two strings. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different. Returns a number between 0 and 1.

Title: levenshtein(s1, s2)
Description: The minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions or substitutions) required to change one string to the other. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different.

Title: mismatches(s1, s2)
Description: Alias for hamming(s1, s2). The number of positions with different characters for two strings of equal length. Strings must be of equal length. Characters of different cases (e.g., a and A) are considered different.

Title: median(x)
Description: The middle value of the set. For even value counts, quantitative values are averaged and ordinal values return the lower value.
quantile_cont(x, 0.5)

Title: mode(x)
Description: The most frequent value.

Title: current_time
Description: Current time (start of current transaction).
Current time (start of current transaction). Note that parentheses should be omitted.

Title: date_diff(part, starttime, endtime)
Description: The number of partition boundaries between the times.

Title: date_part(part, time)
Description: Get subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: date_sub(part, starttime, endtime)
Description: The number of complete partitions between the times.

Title: datediff(part, starttime, endtime)
Description: Alias of date_diff. The number of partition boundaries between the times.

Title: quantile_cont(x, pos)
Description: The interpolated pos-quantile of x for 0 <= pos <= 1, i.e., orders the values of x and returns the pos * (n_nonnull_values - 1)th (zero-indexed) element (or an interpolation between the adjacent elements if the index is not an integer). If pos is a LIST of FLOATs, then the result is a LIST of the corresponding interpolated quantiles.

Title: datepart(part, time)
Description: Alias of date_part. Get subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: datesub(part, starttime, endtime)
Description: Alias of date_sub. The number of complete partitions between the times.

Title: extract(part FROM time)
Description: Get subfield from a time.

Title: get_current_time()
Description: Current time (start of current transaction).

Title: make_time(bigint, bigint, double)
Description: The time for the given parts.

Title: age(timestamp, timestamp)
Description: Subtract arguments, resulting in the time difference between the two timestamps.

Title: age(timestamp)
Description: Subtract from current_date.

Title: century(timestamp)
Description: Extracts the century of a timestamp.

Title: current_timestamp
Description: Returns the current timestamp (at the start of the transaction).
Returns the current timestamp with time zone (at the start of the transaction).

Title: date_diff(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: The number of partition boundaries between the timestamps.

Title: quantile_disc
Description: quantile_disc(x, pos)

The discrete pos-quantile of x for 0 <= pos <= 1, i.e., orders the values of x and returns the greatest(ceil(pos * n_nonnull_values) - 1, 0)th (zero-indexed) element. If pos is a LIST of FLOATs, then the result is a LIST of the corresponding discrete quantiles.

Title: date_part([part, ...], timestamp)
Description: Get the listed subfields as a struct. The list must be constant.

Title: date_part(part, timestamp)
Description: Get subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: date_sub(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: The number of complete partitions between the timestamps.

Title: date_trunc(part, timestamp)
Description: Truncate to specified precision.

Title: datediff(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: Alias of date_diff. The number of partition boundaries between the timestamps.

Title: datepart([part, ...], timestamp)
Description: Alias of date_part. Get the listed subfields as a struct. The list must be constant.

Title: datepart(part, timestamp)
Description: Alias of date_part. Get subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: datesub(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: Alias of date_sub. The number of complete partitions between the timestamps.

Title: datetrunc(part, timestamp)
Description: Alias of date_trunc. Truncate to specified precision.

Title: dayname(timestamp)
Description: The (English) name of the weekday.

Title: argmin(arg, val)
Description: arg_min(arg, val)
Finds the row with the minimum val and calculates the arg expression at that row. Rows where the value of the arg or val expression is NULL are ignored. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: regr_avgx(y, x)
Description: The average of the independent variable for non-NULL pairs, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.

Title: epoch_ms(ms)
Description: Converts ms since epoch to a timestamp.

Title: epoch_ms(timestamp)
Description: Return the total number of milliseconds since the epoch.
Converts a timestamp to milliseconds since the epoch.

Title: epoch_ns(timestamp)
Description: Return the total number of nanoseconds since the epoch.

Title: epoch_us(timestamp)
Description: Return the total number of microseconds since the epoch.

Title: epoch(timestamp)
Description: Converts a timestamp to seconds since the epoch.

Title: extract(field FROM timestamp)
Description: Get subfield from a timestamp.

Title: greatest(timestamp, timestamp)
Description: The later of two timestamps.

Title: isfinite(timestamp)
Description: Returns true if the timestamp is finite, false otherwise.

Title: isinf(timestamp)
Description: Returns true if the timestamp is infinite, false otherwise.

Title: last_day(timestamp)
Description: The last day of the month.

Title: regr_avgy(y, x)
Description: The average of the dependent variable for non-NULL pairs, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.

Title: least(timestamp, timestamp)
Description: The earlier of two timestamps.

Title: make_timestamp(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, double)
Feature: make_timestamp(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, double)
Description: The timestamp for the given parts.

Title: make_timestamp(microseconds)
Description: The timestamp for the given number of µs since the epoch.

Title: monthname(timestamp)
Description: The (English) name of the month.

Title: strftime(timestamp, format)
Description: Converts timestamp to string according to the format string.

Title: strptime(text, format-list)
Description: Converts the string text to timestamp applying the format strings in the list until one succeeds. Throws an error on failure. To return NULL on failure, use try_strptime.

Title: strptime(text, format)
Description: Converts the string text to timestamp according to the format string. Throws an error on failure. To return NULL on failure, use try_strptime.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, timestamp[, offset])
Description: Truncate timestamp by the specified interval bucket_width. Buckets are offset by offset interval.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, timestamp[, origin])
Description: Truncate timestamp by the specified interval bucket_width. Buckets are aligned relative to origin timestamp. origin defaults to 2000-01-03 00:00:00 for buckets that don't include a month or year interval, and to 2000-01-01 00:00:00 for month and year buckets.

Title: to_timestamp(double)
Description: Converts seconds since the epoch to a timestamp with time zone.

Title: regr_count(y, x)
Description: The number of non-NULL pairs.

Title: try_strptime(text, format-list)
Description: Converts the string text to timestamp applying the format strings in the list until one succeeds. Returns NULL on failure.

Title: try_strptime(text, format)
Description: Converts the string text to timestamp according to the format string. Returns NULL on failure.

Title: generate_series(timestamp, timestamp, interval)
Description: Generate a table of timestamps in the closed range, stepping by the interval.

Title: range(timestamp, timestamp, interval)
Description: Generate a table of timestamps in the half open range, stepping by the interval.

Title: current_timestamp
Description: Current date and time (start of current transaction).

Title: get_current_timestamp()
Description: Current date and time (start of current transaction).

Title: greatest(timestamptz, timestamptz)
Description: The later of two timestamps.

Title: isfinite(timestamptz)
Description: Returns true if the timestamp with time zone is finite, false otherwise.

Title: isinf(timestamptz)
Description: Returns true if the timestamp with time zone is infinite, false otherwise.

Title: least(timestamptz, timestamptz)
Description: The earlier of two timestamps.

Title: regr_intercept(y, x)
Description: The intercept of the univariate linear regression line, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.
regr_avgy(y, x) - regr_slope(y, x) * regr_avgx(y, x)

Title: now()
Description: Current date and time (start of current transaction).

Title: transaction_timestamp()
Description: Current date and time (start of current transaction).

Title: age(timestamptz, timestamptz)
Description: Subtract arguments, resulting in the time difference between the two timestamps.

Title: age(timestamptz)
Description: Subtract from current_date.

Title: date_diff(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: The number of partition boundaries between the timestamps.

Title: date_part([part, ...], timestamptz)
Description: Get the listed subfields as a struct. The list must be constant.

Title: date_part(part, timestamptz)
Description: Get subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: date_sub(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: The number of complete partitions between the timestamps.

Title: date_trunc(part, timestamptz)
Description: Truncate to specified precision.

Title: datediff(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: Alias of date_diff. The number of partition boundaries between the timestamps.

Title: regr_r2(y, x)
Description: The squared Pearson correlation coefficient between y and x. Also: The coefficient of determination in a linear regression, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.

Title: datepart([part, ...], timestamptz)
Description: Alias of date_part. Get the listed subfields as a struct. The list must be constant.

Title: datepart(part, timestamptz)
Description: Alias of date_part. Get subfield (equivalent to extract).

Title: datesub(part, startdate, enddate)
Description: Alias of date_sub. The number of complete partitions between the timestamps.

Title: datetrunc(part, timestamptz)
Description: Alias of date_trunc. Truncate to specified precision.

Title: epoch_ms(timestamptz)
Description: Converts a timestamptz to milliseconds since the epoch.

Title: epoch_ns(timestamptz)
Description: Converts a timestamptz to nanoseconds since the epoch.

Title: epoch_us(timestamptz)
Description: Converts a timestamptz to microseconds since the epoch.

Title: extract(field FROM timestamptz)
Description: Get subfield from a TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE.

Title: last_day(timestamptz)
Description: The last day of the month.

Title: make_timestamptz(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, double, string)
Feature: make_timestamptz(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, double, string)
Description: The TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE for the given parts and time zone.

Title: regr_slope(y, x)
Description: The slope of the linear regression line, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.
Returns the slope of the linear regression line, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.
regr_sxy(y, x) / regr_sxx(y, x)

Title: make_timestamptz(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, double)
Feature: make_timestamptz(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint, double)
Description: The TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE for the given parts in the current time zone.

Title: make_timestamptz(microseconds)
Description: The TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE for the given µs since the epoch.

Title: strftime(timestamptz, format)
Description: Converts a TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE value to string according to the format string.

Title: strptime(text, format)
Description: Converts string to TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE according to the format string if %Z is specified.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, timestamptz[, offset])
Description: Truncate timestamptz by the specified interval bucket_width. Buckets are offset by offset interval.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, timestamptz[, origin])
Description: Truncate timestamptz by the specified interval bucket_width. Buckets are aligned relative to origin timestamptz. origin defaults to 2000-01-03 00:00:00+00 for buckets that don't include a month or year interval, and to 2000-01-01 00:00:00+00 for month and year buckets.

Title: time_bucket(bucket_width, timestamptz[, timezone])
Description: Truncate timestamptz by the specified interval bucket_width. Bucket starts and ends are calculated using timezone. timezone is a varchar and defaults to UTC.

Title: generate_series(timestamptz, timestamptz, interval)
Description: Generate a table of timestamps in the closed range (including both the starting timestamp and the ending timestamp), stepping by the interval.

Title: range(timestamptz, timestamptz, interval)
Description: Generate a table of timestamps in the half open range (including the starting timestamp, but stopping before the ending timestamp), stepping by the interval.

Title: current_localtime()
Description: Returns a TIME whose GMT bin values correspond to local time in the current time zone.

Title: regr_sxx(y, x)
Description: The population variance, which includes Bessel's bias correction, of the independent variable for non-NULL pairs, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.

Title: current_localtimestamp()
Description: Returns a TIMESTAMP whose GMT bin values correspond to local date and time in the current time zone.

Title: localtime
Description: Synonym for the current_localtime() function call.

Title: localtimestamp
Description: Synonym for the current_localtimestamp() function call.

Title: timezone(text, timestamp)
Description: Use the date parts of the timestamp in GMT to construct a timestamp in the given time zone. Effectively, the argument is a “local” time.

Title: timezone(text, timestamptz)
Description: Use the date parts of the timestamp in the given time zone to construct a timestamp. Effectively, the result is a “local” time.

Title: union.tag
Description: Dot notation serves as an alias for union_extract.

Title: union_extract(union, 'tag')
Description: Extract the value with the named tags from the union. NULL if the tag is not currently selected.

Title: union_value(tag := any)
Description: Create a single member UNION containing the argument value. The tag of the value will be the bound variable name.

Title: union_tag(union)
Description: Retrieve the currently selected tag of the union as an Enum.

Title: alias(column)
Description: Return the name of the column.

Title: regr_sxy(y, x)
Description: The population covariance, which includes Bessel's bias correction.

Title: checkpoint(database)
Description: Synchronize WAL with file for (optional) database without interrupting transactions.

Title: coalesce(expr, ...)
Description: Return the first expression that evaluates to a non-NULL value. Accepts 1 or more parameters. Each expression can be a column, literal value, function result, or many others.

Title: constant_or_null(arg1, arg2)
Description: If arg2 is NULL, return NULL. Otherwise, return arg1.

Title: count_if(x)
Description: Returns 1 if x is true or a non-zero number.

Title: current_catalog()
Description: Return the name of the currently active catalog. Default is memory.

Title: current_schema()
Description: Return the name of the currently active schema. Default is main.

Title: current_schemas(boolean)
Description: Return list of schemas. Pass a parameter of true to include implicit schemas.

Title: current_setting('setting_name')
Description: Return the current value of the configuration setting.

Title: currval('sequence_name')
Description: Return the current value of the sequence. Note that nextval must be called at least once prior to calling currval.

Title: error(message)
Description: Throws the given error message.

Title: regr_syy(y, x)
Description: The population variance, which includes Bessel's bias correction, of the dependent variable for non-NULL pairs , where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.
The population variance, which includes Bessel's bias correction, of the dependent variable for non-NULL pairs, where x is the independent variable and y is the dependent variable.

Title: force_checkpoint(database)
Description: Synchronize WAL with file for (optional) database interrupting transactions.

Title: gen_random_uuid()
Description: Alias of uuid. Return a random UUID similar to this: eeccb8c5-9943-b2bb-bb5e-222f4e14b687.

Title: getenv(var)
Description: Returns the value of the environment variable var. Only available in the command line client.

Title: hash(value)
Description: Returns a UBIGINT with the hash of the value.

Title: icu_sort_key(string, collator)
Description: Surrogate key used to sort special characters according to the specific locale. Collator parameter is optional. Valid only when ICU extension is installed.

Title: if(a, b, c)
Description: Ternary conditional operator.
Ternary conditional operator; returns b if a, else returns c. Equivalent to CASE WHEN a THEN b ELSE c END.

Title: ifnull(expr, other)
Description: A two-argument version of coalesce.

Title: md5(string)
Description: Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a VARCHAR.

Title: md5_number(string)
Description: Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a HUGEINT.

Title: md5_number_lower(string)
Description: Returns the lower 64-bit segment of the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.
Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.

Title: skewness(x)
Description: The skewness.

Title: md5_number_higher(string)
Description: Returns the higher 64-bit segment of the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.
Returns the MD5 hash of the string as a BIGINT.

Title: nextval('sequence_name')
Description: Return the following value of the sequence.

Title: nullif(a, b)
Description: Return NULL if a = b, else return a. Equivalent to CASE WHEN a = b THEN NULL ELSE a END.
Return null if a = b, else return a. Equivalent to CASE WHEN a = b THEN NULL ELSE a END.

Title: pg_typeof(expression)
Description: Returns the lower case name of the data type of the result of the expression. For PostgreSQL compatibility.

Title: query(query_string_literal)
Description: Table function that parses and executes the query defined in query_string_literal. Only literal strings are allowed. Warning: this function allows invoking arbitrary queries, potentially altering the database state.

Title: query_table(tbl_name)
Description: Table function that returns the table given in tbl_name.

Title: query_table(tbl_names, [by_name])
Description: Table function that returns the union of tables given in tbl_names. If the optional by_name parameter is set to true, it uses UNION ALL BY NAME semantics.

Title: read_blob(source)
Description: Returns the content from source (a filename, a list of filenames, or a glob pattern) as a BLOB. See the read_blob guide for more details.

Title: read_text(source)
Description: Returns the content from source (a filename, a list of filenames, or a glob pattern) as a VARCHAR. The file content is first validated to be valid UTF-8. If read_text attempts to read a file with invalid UTF-8 an error is thrown suggesting to use read_blob instead. See the read_text guide for more details.

Title: sha256(value)
Description: Returns a VARCHAR with the SHA-256 hash of the value.

Title: argmin(arg, val, n)
Description: arg_min(arg, val, n)
Returns a LIST containing the arg expressions for the "bottom" n rows ordered by val ascending. This function is affected by ordering.
The generalized case of arg_min for n values: returns a LIST containing the arg expressions for the top n rows ordered by val descending. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: stddev_pop(x)
Description: The population standard deviation.
sqrt(var_pop(x))

Title: stats(expression)
Description: Returns a string with statistics about the expression. Expression can be a column, constant, or SQL expression.

Title: txid_current()
Description: Returns the current transaction's identifier, a BIGINT value. It will assign a new one if the current transaction does not have one already.

Title: typeof(expression)
Description: Returns the name of the data type of the result of the expression.

Title: uuid()
Description: Return a random UUID similar to this: eeccb8c5-9943-b2bb-bb5e-222f4e14b687.

Title: version()
Description: Return the currently active version of DuckDB in this format.

Title: glob(search_path)
Description: Return filenames found at the location indicated by the search_path in a single column named file. The search_path may contain glob pattern matching syntax.

Title: repeat_row(varargs, num_rows)
Description: Returns a table with num_rows rows, each containing the fields defined in varargs.

Title: cume_dist()
Description: The cumulative distribution: (number of partition rows preceding or peer with current row) / total partition rows.
DOUBLE

Title: dense_rank()
Description: The rank of the current row without gaps; this function counts peer groups.
BIGINT

Title: first_value(expr[ IGNORE NULLS])
Description: Returns expr evaluated at the row that is the first row (with a non-null value of expr if IGNORE NULLS is set) of the window frame.
Same type as expr

Title: stddev(x)
Description: stddev_samp(x)
The sample standard deviation.
sqrt(var_samp(x))

Title: lag(column, 3, 0)
Description: lag(expr[, offset[, default]][ IGNORE NULLS])

Returns expr evaluated at the row that is offset rows (among rows with a non-null value of expr if IGNORE NULLS is set) before the current row within the window frame; if there is no such row, instead return default (which must be of the Same type as expr). Both offset and default are evaluated with respect to the current row. If omitted, offset defaults to 1 and default to NULL.
Same type as expr

Title: last_value(expr[ IGNORE NULLS])
Description: Returns expr evaluated at the row that is the last row (among rows with a non-null value of expr if IGNORE NULLS is set) of the window frame.
Same type as expr

Title: lead(column, 3, 0)
Description: lead(expr[, offset[, default]][ IGNORE NULLS])

Returns expr evaluated at the row that is offset rows after the current row (among rows with a non-null value of expr if IGNORE NULLS is set) within the window frame; if there is no such row, instead return default (which must be of the Same type as expr). Both offset and default are evaluated with respect to the current row. If omitted, offset defaults to 1 and default to NULL.
Same type as expr

Title: nth_value(column, 2)
Description: nth_value(expr, nth[ IGNORE NULLS])
Returns expr evaluated at the nth row (among rows with a non-null value of expr if IGNORE NULLS is set) of the window frame (counting from 1); NULL if no such row.
Same type as expr

Title: ntile(num_buckets)
Description: An integer ranging from 1 to num_buckets, dividing the partition as equally as possible.
BIGINT

Title: percent_rank()
Description: The relative rank of the current row: (rank() - 1) / (total partition rows - 1).
DOUBLE

Title: rank_dense()
Description: The rank of the current row with gaps; same as row_number of its first peer.
BIGINT

Title: rank()
Description: The rank of the current row with gaps; same as row_number of its first peer.
BIGINT

Title: row_number()
Description: The number of the current row within the partition, counting from 1.
BIGINT

Title: var_pop(x)
Description: The population variance, which does not include bias correction.
(sum(x^2) - sum(x)^2 / count(x)) / count(x), var_samp(y, x) * (1 - 1 / count(x))

Title: variance(arg, val)
Description: var_samp(x)
The sample variance, which includes Bessel's bias correction.
(sum(x^2) - sum(x)^2 / count(x)) / (count(x) - 1), var_pop(y, x) / (1 - 1 / count(x))

Title: grouping()
Description: For queries with GROUP BY and either ROLLUP or GROUPING SETS: Returns an integer identifying which of the argument expressions where used to group on to create the current supper-aggregate row.

Title: arg_min_null(arg, val)
Description: Finds the row with the minimum val and calculates the arg expression at that row. Rows where the val expression evaluates to NULL are ignored. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: mean
Description: avg(arg)
Calculates the average of all non-null values in arg.

Title: fsum
Description: sumKahan
fsum(arg)
Calculates the sum using a more accurate floating point summation (Kahan Sum).

Title: list
Description: list(arg)
Returns a LIST containing all the values of a column. This function is affected by ordering.

Title: quantile
Description: quantile_disc(x, pos)

The discrete pos-quantile of x for 0 <= pos <= 1, i.e., orders the values of x and returns the greatest(ceil(pos * n_nonnull_values) - 1, 0)th (zero-indexed) element. If pos is a LIST of FLOATs, then the result is a LIST of the corresponding discrete quantiles.

Title: array_value(index)
Description: Create an ARRAY containing the argument values.

Title: array_cross_product(array1, array2)
Description: Compute the cross product of two arrays of size 3. The array elements can not be NULL.

Title: array_cosine_similarity(array1, array2)
Description: Compute the cosine similarity between two arrays of the same size. The array elements can not be NULL. The arrays can have any size as long as the size is the same for both arguments.

Title: array_cosine_distance(array1, array2)
Description: Compute the cosine distance between two arrays of the same size. The array elements can not be NULL. The arrays can have any size as long as the size is the same for both arguments. This is equivalent to 1.0 - array_cosine_similarity

Compute the cosine distance between two arrays of the same size. The array elements can not be NULL. The arrays can have any size as long as the size is the same for both arguments. This is equivalent to 1.0 - array_cosine_similarity.

Title: array_distance(array1, array2)
Description: Compute the distance between two arrays of the same size. The array elements can not be NULL. The arrays can have any size as long as the size is the same for both arguments.

Title: avg
Description: avg(arg)
Calculates the average of all non-null values in arg.

Title: array_inner_product(array1, array2)
Description: Compute the inner product between two arrays of the same size. The array elements can not be NULL. The arrays can have any size as long as the size is the same for both arguments.

Title: array_negative_inner_product(array1, array2)
Description: Compute the negative inner product between two arrays of the same size. The array elements can not be NULL. The arrays can have any size as long as the size is the same for both arguments. This is equivalent to -array_inner_product

Title: array_dot_product(array1, array2)
Description: Alias for array_inner_product(array1, array2).

Title: array_negative_dot_product(array1, array2)
Description: Alias for array_negative_inner_product(array1, array2).

Title: bit_count(bitstring)
Description: Returns the number of set bits in the bitstring.

Title: bit_length(bitstring)
Description: Returns the number of bits in the bitstring.

Title: bit_position(substring, bitstring)
Description: Returns first starting index of the specified substring within bits, or zero if it's not present. The first (leftmost) bit is indexed 1.
Returns first starting index of the specified substring within bits, or zero if it's not present. The first (leftmost) bit is indexed 1

Title: bitstring(bitstring, length)
Description: Returns a bitstring of determined length.

Title: get_bit(bitstring, index)
Description: Extracts the nth bit from bitstring; the first (leftmost) bit is indexed 0.

Title: length(bitstring)
Description: Alias for bit_length.

Title: cast
Description: The standard SQL syntax for explicit casting is CAST(expr AS TYPENAME), where TYPENAME is a name (or alias) of one of DuckDB's data types.
Examples:
SELECT CAST(i AS VARCHAR) AS i FROM generate_series(1, 3) tbl(i);
 i
 1
 2
 3

Description: DuckDB also supports the shorthand expr::TYPENAME, which is also present in PostgreSQL.
Examples:
SELECT i::DOUBLE AS i FROM generate_series(1, 3) tbl(i);
 i
 1.0
 2.0
 3.0

Title: avg_groupby
Description: avg(arg)
Calculates the average of all non-null values in arg.

Title: count_groupby
Description: count()
Returns the number of rows in a group.

Title: max_groupby
Description: Returns the maximum value present in arg.

Title: min_groupby
Description: Returns the minimum value present in arg.

Title: sum_groupby
Description: Calculates the sum of all non-null values in arg.
